Grass blades stood upright, green soldiers in line,  While the distant creek shimmered, a silver ribbon spun,  Cicadas stitched hours with metallic design,  And the shadows were short, fleeing far from the sun.Children laughed in the orchard, apple-bright and bold,  Their voices like sparrows that dart through the light,  And moths dipped and hovered on wings tipped with gold,  Drawn out from the twilight, enthralled by the sight.  The old dog lay panting where poppies nodded red,  Dreaming of rabbits in the slow, pulsing gloom—  Even the oak trees barely lifted their heads,  Heavy with stories and sap, thick with bloom.’Twas noontide of summer, the season’s high note—  A lull in the music, a pause in the song;  Where time lingers soft, on the edge of a mote,  And the world holds its breath, warm and strong.

instance_metrics.response: ’Twas noontide of summer, and the fields breathed fire—  A hush lay thick on the gold-stricken plain;  Cicadas scrawled music on taut, trembling wire,  And shadows retreated to corners again.  The wheat bowed its heads in a shimmering trance,  Each stalk a sunbeam, alight and agleam;  The river, half-hidden, in slow, silken dance,  Kept weaving its water through bright, drowsy dream.  The children lay sleeping in orchards of green,  Their laughter suspended, their eyelids at rest;  While apples hung heavy, their gloss and their sheen  Painting red promise on boughs in the west.  ’Twas noontide of summer—time hung on the brim,  Dripping its honey through heat-shattered air;  An hour both endless and curiously slim,  A sigh in the sunlight, a gold-threaded prayer.  The blue in the distance grew softer, more deep,  And memory tangled with hope in the light;  ’Twas noontide of summer—the world seemed asleep,  Yet trembled with longing, with wonder, with might.

The silence was not, for the hush carried music—  A distant dog’s bark, and a tractor’s faint moan;  The laughter of children, irreverent, lucid,  Rose up from the creek, bright and wild as a stone. Far off, the river glimmers, a glass  Of memory poured along ancient stones,  And willows whisper to breezes that pass,  Their shadows cool bones and uncovered bones.  The road is a ribbon unraveled by sun,  Mirage and reality fevered and blurred,  Cicadas insist that the world is one  Long, ecstatic, relentless, impossible word.  ’Twas noontide of summer, the meadow’s deep sigh  Hung over the world as a velvet refrain;  Time was a dragonfly skimming the sky,  Alive in a moment too bright to retain.  So I lay in the hush, among asters and clover,  Heart slow with sunlight, the day far from over—  And wished in that golden suspension of noon  That the summer might never surrender to moon.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They scatter like sparrows at dawn’s first light,  Flitting from shadow to shadow, eager-eyed,  Each wingbeat a whisper of what might go wrong.They gather in flurried congregation  Above the bed where I toss and turn,  A parliament of doubts, all clamoring  With brittle voices—what if, what then, what now?My God, how many are my fears—  I count them on fingertips raw from worry,  Measure them in heartbeats skipped and hasty,  In silent prayers whispered behind clenched teeth.Some are small, gray mice in the cupboard,  Nibbling at dreams I dare not name aloud.  Others loom large, bears at the threshold,  Heavy and hulking, impossible to shoo away.And yet, in the hush between tremblings,  A sliver of calm, soft as rain on dry earth—  Reminds me: the dawn also counts its losses,  Yet still it rises, golden and unafraid.My God, how many are my fears!  But how many more are the mercies I wake to,  How many more the hopes that hold me upright,  How many more the mornings yet to come?

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They rise like mist at break of day,  A thousand voices in my ears  That whisper doubts I can’t allay. They perch upon my trembling chest,  A parliament of phantom seers  Who prophesy unrest on rest.  They sprinkle salt upon my dreams,  And paint the dawn with anxious hue,  They tangle hope in crooked seams,  And turn the sky from gold to blue.Yet in the counting, something shifts—  A gentle hand, a hush, a light—  The dark mathematics softly lifts  Its sum dissolves within the night.  I turn, I breathe, I see anew—  The fears are many, true as rain,  But faith, that silent river, too  Moves quietly to ease the pain.My God, how many are my fears—  But how much more your love appears.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They cluster at the edge of dawn,  Arriving before the birds’ first song—  Uninvited guests, draped in bitter years.  They settle in the hollow of my throat,  Winding tight as a rosary of regrets,  Each bead an echo, never quite forgot,  Each prayer a promise I haven’t kept.  In the darkness, they multiply—  Shadows twisting upon the ceiling,  Breathing with me, counting sighs,  A parliament forever convening.  Some are small—mice beneath the floor—  Scurrying with delicate, silent claws.  Others are beasts pounding at the door,  Heavy with hunger, bristling with jaws.  Yet, even as I count and name  The shapes and sizes of my dread,  A softer voice calls through the rain,  A gentle hand upon my head.  Oh, teach me, God, to weigh my fears  Against the quiet pulsing of the earth,  And let the dawn, in silver tears,  Wash away all terror’s worth.

instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They crowd my waking, shadowed hours—  A field of thistles, wild and fierce,  Unyielding in their painted power. instance_metrics.response: My God, how many are my fears!  They gather like dusk at the windowpane,  Whispering in voices older than rain—  The hush before thunder, the trembling years. It is the pause after laughter,  When the room has emptied out,  And the words you meant to say  Hang unsaid like dust in the rafters.Yet, lonely is a seed in waiting,  A silent promise under soil—  One day, roots will find their neighbors,  And green will split the dark in joy.  Sometimes, loneliness is just  The space before the birth of song,  A night so quiet, you can hear  The stars, calling you along.

instance_metrics.response: Lonely is the song of midnight rain  Tapping lightly on the attic windowpane,  A silver hush that seeps into the bone,  Where shadows gather, weaving dreams alone.  Lonely is the shadow on the stair,  Trailing silence through cold, empty air—  A chair unfilled, a cup untouched by hands,  The echo of a voice time reprimands.It’s the restless moon seeking company  In bruised indigo, over an unlit sea;  A moth circling light it cannot claim,  A whispered promise that never came.Yet loneliness, a garden left to wild,  Nurtures seeds the world has yet beguiled—  A trembling hope, a fragile, golden sound  Unfolding petals when no one’s around.So hold the hush, the ache, the gentle sting,  Let it teach you what solitude can bring:  The poetry within a quiet heart,  The art of loving every separate part.For in the hollow where the world falls away,  Lonely becomes the dawn, the start of day—  A single voice rising, clear and true,  Learning, at last, to sing just for you.

It is the hush of midnight  when laughter fades to ghosts,  the clock’s relentless ticking  marking each ache,  each hollow between breaths.Yet sometimes loneliness  is a seed, shivering beneath the snow,  longing for dawn,  dreaming of roots,  craving the reckless abundance  of spring. instance_metrics.response: On the scene came Christ The Lord,  Not with peace but with a sword—  Not with lilies for the meek,  But with thunder for the weak,  He strode through shadows cast by doubt,  His eyes alight, his voice a shout.He did not whisper gentle things  To trembling hearts or wounded kings;  He did not weave a patterned spell  Of tranquil days where lovers dwell.  Instead, he raised the iron blade  And with his coming, clarity made.Where lies had tangled roots in earth,  He split them open, gave truth birth.  The fields of comfort scorched and seared,  The walls of silence disappeared;  Old certainties were cleft in twain  By every syllable of pain.He summoned siblings into wrath,  Divided fathers, mothers’ path—  To bear a fire, to spark a storm,  To tear the fabric of the norm.  The gentle lamb now roared aloud,  And shattered every stony cloud.For revolution wrapped in light,  For mercy sharpened for the fight,  He brought no balm for wounds ignored—  On the scene came Christ The Lord.

instance_metrics.response: On the scene came Christ The Lord,  not with peace but with a sword.  Midnight trembled on the hill,  olive branches gripped and still.  Moonlight slipped through leaves like doubt,  casting shadows, casting out  old illusions—soft and warm—  stripped away by thunder’s form.He came not clothed in poet’s rhyme  nor gentle balm for grievous time,  but fire within His eyes,  voice that split the shallow lies  of comfort, rote, and ancient sin—  He carved the line to walk within.A sword, not steel but searing word,  slicing soul from herd and herd—  "Follow me, but count the cost,  fields unplowed and bridges lost."  Brothers shattered, fathers torn,  wheat and chaff no longer sworn  to mingle in the autumn air—  He called the willing, few who dare.On the scene came Christ, a flame,  not to pacify or tame,  but to upend, to restore,  to mend the world by breaking more;  the peace He brings, a paradox—  truth’s blade against the ancient locks  that bind the heart in dust and hoard—  On the scene came Christ The Lord.

He sundered silence, tore the seam  Of ancient law and broken dream,  The gentle lion, fierce and kind,  Who scattered power, called the blind  To see the kingdoms, grim and new,  Rising from the blood and dew. instance_metrics.response: The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,  A whispering spiral of hunger and hope—  In the hush of the garden, where innocence fell,  Desire wore scales and the truth wore a cloak.  A tongue flicks silver at the skin of the red,  Temptation distilled in a drop of dew—  One bite and the world shifted, fled  From the shade of its comfort, the gold of its hue.  Oh, the garden remembers the press of a heel,  The laughter that faded, the echo of blame;  A coil in the grass, a fruit's bitter peal—  The cost of a question, the birth of a name.  We tell it in murmurs, in pulpits and dreams,  Of wisdom and wanting, of sorrow and sin.  Yet under the apples, the sunlight still streams—  The snake and the garden begin once again.  For every new morning, a hunger will rise,  A gleam in the branches, a shiver of skin—  And somewhere a story is told through the eyes  Of someone who dares let the knowledge begin.

instance_metrics.response: Everyone has a fear—  A shadow wound tight in the hollow of the rib,  A secret pulse beneath the laughter,  Sewn in the lining of old jackets  Or pressed between the pages of a book  We pretend we never read. Others fear the trembling of bridges,  Or the memory of hands that let go too soon,  The possibility of words left unsaid,  Or the certainty of time’s cruel forward march.  We carry them, these small, jeweled talismans—  A spider’s leg, a shattered promise,  The moment before the phone rings  When everything could change.  Yet in the heart’s dim-lit corners,  Where fear hums a private lullaby,  We find ourselves—braver, perhaps,  For having walked with trembling steps  Through the wilderness of our own undoing,  And learned to cup a flicker of hope  In shaking hands,  Long after the dark has passed.

There are those who dread the tick of clocks—  The thinning thread of borrowed time;  Or faces lost in shifting flocks,  The echoing of steps behind.  Some fears are worn like favorite sweaters,  Familiar in their knitted chill;  Others dart like startled letters,  Unread, unanswered, waiting still.  What binds us is the secret sense  That something fragile lies within—  A heart too open, skin too thin,  A hope that dares at consequence.  But see: in every trembling hand,  A spark survives, a will to stand;  For courage does not mean to lack  A fear, but rather, not turn back—  To carry on though shadows near,  For everyone, yes, everyone has a fear.

instance_metrics.response: Everyone has a fear—  a root curled in the dark soil  beneath the ribcage, quiet  as a moth’s wing beating  against a closed jar.  Even the granite-faced man  at the corner coffee shop  worries over the breaking of bread,  the brief tremor in a wrist,  a phone call unanswered at dawn.  Fear is the shadow  that trails behind the dancer,  the gap between footsteps  and the ground.  It is the silence after laughter,  the echo that doesn’t return.  Some cradle it softly,  whispering its name  like a promise or a prayer—  others lock it in their chests,  wrapped in silk,  a secret heirloom. Thou art my God alone;  When dusk dissolves the world to bone,  And in the silent, shivering air  No other comfort lingers there—  I turn, unspoken, toward Thy face,  A shadow seeking sovereign grace.  Before the wheat’s unyielding gold  Breaks gently from its earthen hold,  Before the stars are sifted free  From night’s abiding tapestry,  My longing soul, unsatisfied,  Calls out where ancient dreams reside.  The rivers split the thirsty land,  They trace the secrets of Thy hand;  Through desert dust and fevered hours,  My flesh remembers Eden’s bowers.  Yet only echoes fill my days,  Unless Thy mercy lights my gaze.  O God! In mornings steeped in dew,  In griefs I carry, sharp and few—  I learn to name Thee, one by one,  Creator, Keeper, Paraclete, Son.  From hollowed heart and marrowed bone,  O God—Thou art my God alone.

instance_metrics.response: O God! Thou art my God alone;  In silent dawns and thunder’s moan,  No other name my lips have known—  No other refuge when I groan.  When shadows stretch across the sand,  And thirsting earth forgets the rain,  Thy presence, gentle as a hand,  Restores my faith and mends my pain.  A whisper deep within the soul,  A fire that will not be undone,  Thy light remakes the broken whole,  And from the night, calls forth the sun.  Through gardens bright and deserts bare,  Above the stars, beneath the stone—  Wherever hearts are laid to prayer,  O God! Thou art my God alone.  Not fashioned by the works of men,  Nor carved in idol, dream, or creed,  But living breath within my ken,  Thy mercy, ever-present need.  So let me seek, with longing eyes,  Thy countenance before the throne,  And live, until all longing dies:  O God! Thou art my God alone.

Thou art my God alone.The rivers run with ancient lore,  Mountains echo Your name once more.  Through deserts dry and winter’s frost,  I seek Your hand, however lost.  All idols born of dust and bone  Are pale before Your sovereign throne,  For every hunger, hope, and moan—  O God! Thou art my God alone.In joy’s full tide, or sorrow’s wake,  In trembling calm or storms that break,  My soul remembers, bows, and clings  To You, the source of every spring.  No temple made by hands contains  The mystery that still remains;  In every tear, in every tone—  O God! Thou art my God alone.So through the years, by night and sun,  My song, my refuge, only One.  Till stars dissolve and time is gone—  O God! Thou art my God alone.

The world’s bright idols, brittle, fall—  False gold and glass in morning light;  Yet in Thy presence, over all,  The darkness breaks, the heart grows bright.  O God, my God, there is no other,  No shelter save Thy steadfast hand,  My Father, Friend, my secret Brother,  Who leads me through this silent land.  So let me dwell beneath Thy wings—  A song when daylight’s hopes have flown;  O God! My heart forever sings:  Thou art my God, and mine alone.

instance_metrics.response: Rewind life and remember:  the hush between two heartbeats,  how summer’s dust tangled in your hair,  the way laughter ran reckless  through the old kitchen—  cracked linoleum, the warmth of bread,  voices weaving in and out of memory  like golden strands unraveling.Recall the bright scrape of a bicycle  on gravel roads,  the sharp joy of unbroken skin,  and the promise, whispered  on the backs of fireflies,  that nothing ends, not really—  just changes shape  in the slow turn of years.Rewind to the window,  where rain painted stories  on glass, and you pressed your palm  to the cold—  hoping to feel the world outside,  to catch the drifting echo  of a dream unspoken,  still waiting in the wings.Remember the faces—  how they softened in lamplight,  how time spun them farther apart  but not away.  Hold the silence before a word,  the shadow before a dawn—  rewind, remember:  life was always more  than the sum of what was lost.

instance_metrics.response: Rewind life and remember:  the hush before the thunder,  when dusk’s gold fingers  braided summer hair;  the old oak’s green cathedral,  echoing with laughter  we once scattered like sparrows  in the honey-misted air.Rewind life and remember:  the clatter of dishes in kitchens  where secrets simmered low,  the warmth of hands,  the silent language of glances  sewn across crowded tables  with invisible thread.Rewind life and remember:  the ache in your chest  when the world first cracked open,  when the sky’s bruised purple  promised something vast—  a hope, a leaving, a return.Let memory spiral backward—  each frame a leaf,  each face a lantern  glowing in the fog of days.  What we lost,  what we carried,  what we broke and what we mended  in the tender machinery of time.Rewind life and remember:  not to stay,  but to gather—  the soft architecture of joy,  the scaffolding of sorrow,  until the reel unspools  and you step forward,  lighter,  knowing the way.

I studied the language of moss,  Learned to speak by the hush of beetle wings,  To count by the rhythm of falling leaves.  I was patient, waiting for the thunder  That would split the soil,  For the strange, impossible green  Of a shoot piercing darkness.One morning, my own shadow startled me—  Tall and tremulous, stretching beyond  The confines of furrow and fear.  I rose, vertebrae unfurling,  Heart a stubborn seed.Now, I drink the sky in lungfuls,  Trade the hush for a song—  I remember the earth,  But walk on my own two feet,  Carrying the sunlight home.

instance_metrics.response: I was a grovelling creature once,  Low to the soil, where roots whisper,  Where footsteps above meant storms—  I curled beneath the web of fallen leaves,  Listening to beetles’ sermons and the sigh  Of mud pressed close to my trembling skin.The world was a cavernous mouth then,  Teeth of stone and tongue of moss.  I cowered from the sunlight’s golden lash,  My hunger a pebble rolling in a dark gut.  Dreams were for the birds,  Their songs too bright for my hollow ears.But time, that subtle gardener,  Fed me with the patience of rain.  I drank the slow drip of hope—  A green blade pressed from my spine,  The courage to stand, even as storms returned,  Even as old fears gnawed my ankles.Now, I walk upright—  Not always graceful, but tall enough  To glimpse the blue above the bramble.  Still, I remember the press of earth,  How survival is the first prayer,  And rising, even inch by inch,  Is a kind of flight.

instance_metrics.response: People are happy, or so it appears—  Their laughter unfurls like ribbons in air,  Sunshine reflected in crystalline tears,  A masquerade waltzing through days unaware. Yet deep in the quiet, when twilight descends,  Longings may flutter like wings in the chest—  Still, warmth in the hand of a lover or friend  Teaches the heart to feel safe, to feel blessed.People are happy—not always, not all—  But sometimes the sunlight breaks through the gray,  Sometimes the simplest of pleasures recall  Lost, golden mornings that brighten the day. instance_metrics.response: People are happy in the fluted morning,  when the sky is a spilled bowl of apricot light,  and the cat stretches on the neighbor’s fence,  tail curling like a question mark,  answering nothing but the sun’s warmth.People are happy in the half-second hush  between pouring coffee and first sip—  when their thoughts float gentle as moths  against the window’s thin pane:  the world is patient, the world is soft.In the staccato song of crosswalks,  amid the ascent of buses and laughter,  children launch paper airplanes,  lettered with wishes, over the traffic’s roar;  and for a moment—just a moment—  gravity is less certain,  and hope hovers.People are happy in the quiet hours,  when rain tiptoes on the roof  and memory flickers in lamplight,  when they wear old sweaters  and sit in chairs that remember them.Happiness is a tapestry—  threaded through with longing,  bright in fragments,  never finished, always begun  by the hands that lift the latch,  open the door,  and step—unguarded—into morning.

Once the rush of rain sang here—  Lilies in flood, frogs in chorus,  Everything ripe with shimmer.  Now reeds rattle dry against bone,  Their shadows thin and restless  On the cracked, reluctant clay.  Each small oasis shrinks, still dreaming  Of clouds returning, of whispering nights  When stars would float like lanterns  In wide, uninterrupted dark.  But above, the sky is a hard, pale shell,  And hope gathers, low and silent,  Around the shrinking circles of water—  A heron waits, almost invisible  In patience, in longing, in blue.  Perhaps with time, a distant thunder  Will stumble across these tired valleys,  And the pools will swell again,  Brimming with the memory of abundance—  But for now, just a few dwindling pools remain,  Holding the world’s last glimmer  Of green, and silver, and possibility.

instance_metrics.response: Just a few dwindling pools remain  Where water once uncoiled in laughter,  Cradled by banks of grass and grain,  Singing bright hymns to the ever-after.  Now, silence drapes the cracked terrain,  Wind scrawls its secrets in the dust,  Ripples are memories—fragile, plain—  Reflections dulled by time and rust.  Here, dragonflies hover as living ghosts,  Their jeweled wings aching for yesterday,  Where frogs croaked choruses, joy engrossed,  And minnows darted in silver ballet.  The sun kneels low—compassion spent—  While roots reach deeper, parched and thin.  Reeds whisper prayers in dry lament  For the world as it might have been.  Still, hope huddles in these shrinking blue,  A shimmer trembling on the edge of loss,  Promising rain, or something new—  A memory kept, no matter the cost.  For life clings fierce to what remains,  In dwindling pools, in remembered rains.

Just a few dwindling pools remain—  Yet in their depths, the world sustains.

instance_metrics.response: When I am happy, the world leaks color—  Soft as sunlight on a windowsill,  Even paper birds begin to flutter  With a secret, laughing thrill.  Clouds uncurl their silver linings,  Thistles hush their prickled spines,  Old regrets lose all their pining,  And the hourglass forgets its lines.  When I am happy, every sparrow  Builds its nest inside my chest;  Shy hopes, once thin and narrow,  Grow bold enough to leave the nest.  The city’s murmur turns to song,  Each face—a flicker of surprise,  And roads I have walked so long  Appear in fresher, friendlier guise.  When I am happy, I am water—  Reflecting sky, both blue and wild,  A ripple running ever farther,  A laugh released by a child.  Time becomes a drowsy river,  Yesterday and tomorrow blend,  When I am happy, I remember  Life is simple, in the end.

A memory, perhaps—a breath of frost—  Slipped through the latticed window, counting cost  Of every secret kept, each whispered plea  That vanished in the hush of memory.The clock, a patient warden, ticked the hours  In rhythm with the sighing of the flowers  As petals closed, and silence thickened, deep,  While somewhere in the house, a child’s sleep  Was restless with the weight of ancient tales—  Of wolves, of stars, of ships with tattered sails,  All drifting through the corridors of mind,  Invisible, yet never left behind.That night—its darkness lined with velvet thread—  Unfolded like a story never read,  Where hope and fear moved softly, hand in hand,  And time slipped by, a tide of drifting sand.  One dark, dark night—it was long ago—  But still it lingers, in the hush, the snow,  A shadow on the threshold, standing near,  A story waiting, always, to appear.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago,  When the moon was a coin and the air was low,  A whispering wind slipped under the door,  And shadows grew tall on the creaking floor.  The village slept, its lanterns dim,  While old oaks pressed at the window’s rim,  And someone hummed, from the courtyard deep,  A lullaby lost to the folds of sleep.  The stars had gathered in secret bands,  Threading their stories through spectral hands,  Each pulse of light a remembered name  Burned bright with longing, or sorrow, or shame.  One dark, dark night—a memory’s trace,  A footstep unheard in an empty place,  The smell of the earth, the hush of a cry,  A moth at the pane, a bat in the sky.  I walk through the hush with a lantern’s glow,  Tracing the places I used to know,  One dark, dark night—so long ago—  I carry its silence wherever I go.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago,  When the moon was a button sewn tight to the sky  And the wind whispered secrets that only ghosts know,  And the foxes flashed crimson, and shadows drew nigh.  Old houses, hunched low, kept their stories concealed,  With windows like eyelids half-closed in a dream;  The mist curled its fingers across every field,  And silence held sway like a silver-bright queen.  I wandered the lanes where the wild briars cling,  Where gravel spoke softly beneath wary feet;  The air tasted chilly, yet sweet as the spring,  And time lost its way in the hush of the street.  Somewhere far off, an owl started to cry—  A question, a warning, a memory’s trace;  Even the stars seemed to shudder and sigh,  Retreating far back in the velvet of space.  One dark, dark night—it was long ago,  But the hush and the wonder still cling to my mind:  A world softly breathing, mysterious, slow,  Where the past and the present are endlessly twined.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago,  The moon, a mere rumor behind cloud and crow,  Tattered trees whispered secrets in silverless air,  Dreams curled in corners, too frightened to dare.  A clock in the distance ticked hollow and slow,  While shadows knit shadows on frost-bitten snow,  The guttering lanterns held close to their gleam,  And silence unfurled, thick as sleep or a dream.  One dark, dark night—when the world held its breath,  The stars shied from watch, and the wind carried death.  Old doors remembered the groan of the past,  A blackbird’s lone warning, a footstep too fast.  I wandered that night through the hush and the cold,  My thoughts braided tightly with stories half-told,  The branches reached out with their spindled despair,  Yet something persisted, unseen in the air.  For in that darkness, the memory grows—  Of a lantern once lit, of a truth no one knows.  One dark, dark night—so distant, so near—  The shadows still whisper, and someone still hears.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago,  When silence pressed thick on the frosted pane,  And lantern light stuttered its trembling glow  On streets drowned in shadows and cold, slow rain.  Clouds bundled secrets in velvet swathes—  No moon to scatter their careful lies.  Window to window, the hush withdrew  Like a sigh from the bones of the sleeping skies.  A child with a candle, clutched in her palms,  Crept past the hearth where old embers slept,  Each footstep echoing history’s psalms  Of promises whispered, and promises kept.  She tiptoed past doorways, past memories worn,  Past portraits who watched with unblinking gaze—  In that dark, dark night, she would not be forlorn,  Though the world seemed adrift in a midnight maze.  For sometimes the blackness is velvet and deep,  A cradle for wishes too bold for the day;  And sometimes the silence is sacred, a sweep  Of time set aside for what hearts cannot say.  One dark, dark night—it was long ago—  Yet echoes still linger where hope used to grow.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago,  When the moon wore a shroud of mist as a cloak,  And the stars huddled close, afraid to show  Their trembling faces through the yew trees’ smoke. The cobblestones echoed with footsteps unseen,  Each echo a memory, distant and strained,  Where lamp-lit windows flickered between  The now and the never, the loved and the pained.  One dark, dark night—when the clocks forgot time,  And gardens exhaled silver breaths on the grass,  A child with a lantern wove through the grime,  Chasing a song only night birds could pass.  She carried a secret, older than tears,  A lullaby sung from the bones of the earth;  The night held its breath, awash in old fears,  Waiting for dawn and the promise of birth.  So remember, dear heart, as the moon slips from sight,  The world was remade on that dark, dark night.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago,  When the world lay soft in a quilt of snow,  The wind was a whisper, a spectral sigh,  And the moon painted secrets on roofs up high. Beneath the moon’s indifference,  You rise, a fevered prayer,  A bridge between dust and hope,  A whisper, a dare. instance_metrics.response: Fire:  a word, a wound—  a tongue that speaks in crackling syllables,  brighter than memory, older than dream.  Once, it was flint and hunger’s hope,  a spark trembling in the cave-dark,  hands cupping warmth as if it were miracle,  as if it were love.  Now, fire is both feast and fury:  it sighs in hearths,  kisses bread to crust and apple to gold,  whirls in dancers’ hands and festival torches,  and yet—  it licks at forests,  devours the old wood, the ant’s home,  the fox’s den, the nests that held daylight.  We meet fire on winter nights,  telling stories in its glow,  watching shadows paint the walls  as if the flames themselves remember  all they have seen—  lightning in the grasslands,  ships set alight for lost kings,  the candles trembling on a birthday cake.  Fire:  an omen, a blessing,  the red thread woven through  the fabric of beginnings and ends.  We name it carefully,  we guard it,  and in its restless, golden gaze  we see ourselves—  bright, hungry,  dangerous, alive.

The mountains loom, stern as old regrets,  Their snowy shoulders wrapped in mourning shawls.  Children chase paper kites, wild and bright,  Against a sky that cannot decide—  To weep, or to forgive.  No rain for weeks, the pomegranates shrivel  In the bazaars. Still the sellers sing,  Their voices weaving with the wind—  An endless, brittle hope.  The forecast speaks in gentle riddles:  A sunbeam threading the mosque’s shadow,  A whisper of wind through bullet-scarred walls.  “Tomorrow, perhaps, rain will come,”  But Kabul knows tomorrow is a trembling thing,  Balanced on the edge of prayer and memory.  Tonight, the city will listen to the weather,  Cradling wishes like warm bread,  Daring to believe the clouds might, at last,  Bring something other than sorrow.

instance_metrics.response: Busy old fool, unruly Sun,  whose golden knuckles rap the glass,  what right have you to wake the world—  to scatter dreams where shadows pass? You ride your chariot through these blinds,  ignoring every plea and praise.  Yet, old bright tyrant, take your bow—  we’ll draw the curtains, steal the hour,  and in the hush you cannot reach,  lie tangled, sweet, and gently soured.

A woman on a park bench,  her laughter a wild bird set free;  the old man with stories in his pockets,  hands trembling as he unfolds them;  the child who waves from a swing,  her eyes bright with unnamed tomorrows.We meet—sometimes with thunder,  sometimes on soft, unnoticed feet—  and leave echoes in each other’s corridors:  the borrowed umbrella on a rainy day,  a shared secret, heavy in the hush  of midnight confessions;  hands that brush in passing,  sparking possibility or comfort.There are those who stay,  becoming the gentle architecture  of our memory’s home,  and those who leave,  their footsteps lingering in the dust  of a path we travel onward.In the end, each meeting  is a constellation, a brief flare  of light against the wide night.  We are both map and traveler,  marked by the stars of those  we’ve encountered—  and changed, forever,  by the journey we share.

instance_metrics.response: We meet many people in life,  Like rain on a passing window—  Some linger, some slip in rivulets,  Trickling down and away,  Leaving misty fingerprints in their wake.A laugh, a glance, a fleeting kindness,  The brush of hands in a crowded room,  A stranger’s story told in the hush of night,  Or the silent pact of two souls  Who recognize each other  By the mirrored ache in their eyes.We meet many people in life,  Collectors of moments,  Carriers of secret storms,  Each with a map etched in quiet scars  And constellations of hope  Scattered across their inner skies.Some will carve their names  On the soft bark of our memory,  Blooming every spring  With the promise of what-ifs  And the fragrance of nostalgia.Others will pass like shadows,  Soft-footed, almost imagined—  Yet, even a shadow  Is shaped by the light  Of our becoming.We meet many people in life—  Each encounter a note,  A brief harmony  In the long, unfinished song  Of who we are becoming.

Here, every exit is named for a sorrow or fear:  Dead End of Regret, Overpass of Despair,  Yet travelers gather in silence, drawn near  By the pulse of the road and the chill in the air.  I search for a turnoff that destiny keeps,  A signpost of mercy scrawled deep in the dust,  But the highways of woes are paved over our sleeps,  And the journey is driven by memory’s rust.  Still, in the hush as the dawn paints the sky,  Hope blinks on the verge where the blacktop gives way—  A flower defies the asphalt with a sigh,  And dreams hitchhike home with the promise of day.

instance_metrics.response: At the highways of woes, where the tarmac is scarred  by the tread of regrets and the weight of the marred,  I wander at dusk with my memories trailing—  a convoy of heartaches, the past’s endless railing. The lanes split in shadows—grief’s fork in the road—  one path is forgiveness, the other a load  of burdens I carry, unshed and unspoken,  the rearview reflecting what’s broken, not broken.  I pass exit signs painted with names I once knew,  their letters dissolving in drizzles of blue;  the mile-markers count all the distance I’ve lost  while calculating hope against love’s heavy cost.  But far on the verge, where the blacktop meets sky,  a glimmer of dawn paints the dark with a sigh.  At the highways of woes, I pause and remember:  each journey through midnight is answered by ember—  for even in sorrow, the road curves toward light,  and the highway of woes cannot last through the night.

instance_metrics.response: A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,  She wakes before the breaking day—  Her laughter spins among the wheat,  Her bare feet dancing in the peat.  The cockerel’s crow, the cows’ slow gaze  Bear witness to her sunlit ways,  Her apron bright with stains of jam,  Her hands the gentlest in the land.  She hums a tune to greet the dawn,  A song her own, the orchard’s drawn  To every step she takes in dew—  A promise kept, a hope renewed.  Her eyes reflect the open sky,  The wind and earth and swallows fly  Beside her as she mends and sows,  The wild rose blooming where she goes.  Her laughter lifts in fields of rye,  A melody that will not die.  She gathers eggs, she shapes the bread,  With strength and honey lightly spread.  A farmer’s wife, both young and gay—  She keeps the world from slipping gray.  In every furrow, bloom, and bee,  She folds her joy into the lea.

Bare feet dancing on dew-soaked grass,  Morning’s gold in her hair amassed,  She scatters seed with nimble hand,  Dreams sown deep into the land.In checkered skirt and sun-bright scarf,  She cups her palm to the calf’s soft heart,  Her cheeks all rosy from wind’s embrace,  The meadow’s song upon her face.  She hums of harvest, rain, and sun,  Of seasons turned and work well done,  Of evenings spent by candlelight,  Soft-woven tales that warm the night.Her laughter rings through orchard shade  As apples drop and shadows fade.  No silver spoon or silken thread,  But wildflowers crown her head.  With hope as sturdy as the plough,  She walks the furrows, keeps her vow—  A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,  Planting joy along the way.

instance_metrics.response: God is the refuge of his saints—  within the trembling hush of night,  where starlight threads through cedar limbs  and hushes worry’s bitter bite.  No tempest wind, no iron grief  can scale the ramparts of his care;  his shadow, broad as summer leaves,  is shelter for the meekest prayer.They gather trust like grains of sand  and pour them at his altar’s side;  their hearts, a lantern in his hand,  burn steady as the oceans wide.  No ancient sorrow, loss, or thorn  can mar the rock where faith is sown;  each tear, each hope, each joy reborn—  he knows them all, and calls them home.In silent chambers of the soul  where doubts parade in borrowed masks,  he builds a fortress, whole and sure,  from answers to unspoken asks.  So saints, whose names the world forgets,  are cradled on a mighty breast—  God is their refuge, steadfast yet,  their harbor and their quiet rest.

instance_metrics.response: Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,  To fold herself into the thinnest seam  Of shadow, slip beneath the quiet tide  Of covers, drifting in a cotton dream. She wants the hush of rain against the sill,  The muffled breath of dust along the floor,  A hush so deep her thoughts grow soft and still—  She wishes only to become a door,  Leading to nothing—wood and silent air,  A passage no one enters, unaware. She gathers silence, folds it in her chest,  And steps, half-willing, into hopeful light—  The longing for retreat becomes her rest,  The courage to emerge, her quiet fight.

A child laughs, his eyes bright as wild poppy fields,  not knowing yet of borders, of lines drawn in dust—  the world is a puzzle, and peace is the yield  when we handle each piece with tenderness and trust.  I respect the call to prayer, and the silence that follows,  the incense that rises, the bells that chime noon,  the stories of ancestors, swallowed by hollows,  their legacies woven into ancient monsoon.  In the end, what are we but travelers here—  seeking warmth, seeking shelter, seeking some sign  that kindness endures, that love perseveres,  that your world and mine can, in harmony, shine?

instance_metrics.response: I respect, another man’s religion, or color or creed—  For I have seen the sunrise from a thousand borrowed skies,  Drunk rain from unfamiliar wells, felt the hush of foreign prayers  Slip like silk between my fingers—gentle, unafraid,  Each word a different blossom in a garden made of faith.  I have walked through temples lit with trembling gold,  Heard the call to worship trembling from a distant minaret,  Watched candles flicker in a quiet pew,  Sat cross-legged, listening in circles, stories passing from tongue to tongue—  A tapestry of hearts, stitched strong by difference.  I have seen the laughter of a child, skin deep as mahogany,  And caught my own reflection in eyes not my own;  We are all the same fragile wish upon the morning—  Yearning, stumbling, seeking peace in the space between our hands.  If I am to build a home, let it be with open doors,  Walls wide enough for every voice, every song,  For I respect the mosaic, the grand unfinished poem  Of another man’s religion, his color, his creed—  And in his song, I find my own completion.

instance_metrics.response: I respect, another man’s religion, or color or creed—  for what is a soul but a flicker of need,  a hunger for meaning, for kinship, for light,  for places to gather, to grieve, to unite?  The world is a patchwork of prayers and of songs,  of eyes that see beauty in rights and in wrongs;  in temples of marble, or fields of tall grass,  we whisper our hopes as the centuries pass.  Your god may wear sandals, a veil, or a star,  with verses in Sanskrit, in Latin, or far—  but the hush of devotion, the warmth of the sun,  reminds us that humankind pulses as one.  I respect, for I know that my path is my own,  and yours is a river that flowed from your home;  let us meet at the crossroads, exchange a kind glance,  and honor the difference that gives us this chance—  to cherish the stories, the rituals, the skin,  the languages spoken, the faces we’re in;  for peace is a promise, a seed that we sow  when we honor the lives that we’ll never quite know.

instance_metrics.response: A poet loses his power for poetry—  as though a hand, grasping wind,  finds only the slip and hush of emptiness.  Words, once bright coins pressed  from the mint of longing,  now fall dull as rainwater on stone.  He walks the rooms of his mind  where once lanterns of metaphor swung,  where memory flared in lyric colors—  now all is gray, a silent museum  of absent music.Who stole his tongue?  Did the river dry up, or did grief  build dams behind his ribs?  He scrawls a line, watches it wilt  like cut flowers in thirsty vases.  The seasons ignore his pleading:  Spring keeps her promises to the grass,  not to him.Yet, on sleepless nights,  he cracks open his old notebooks,  tracing faded ink with trembling hands—  hoping, perhaps, for a spark’s return,  for the gods of the page  to whisper just one quicksilver line  before dawn spills its honey  and erases the dreams.But for now, he waits—  unstrung, un-rhymed,  a witness to hush,  as the world spins  and the poem inside him  remains unwritten,  a shadow on the tip of his tongue.

instance_metrics.response: A poet loses his power for poetry—  as if the wind forgot the bell’s brass tongue,  or night misplaced the secret of its shadow.  His fingers hover, uncertain, above the page  where words once flowered like after-rain poppies  flushed with the ache to be named.He stalks the rooms of his skull,  each wall echoing the memory of a line,  each window painted shut  with yesterday’s metaphors.  His tongue, an unstrung lute,  knows only silence,  and silence, too, is a kind of grief.He listens for the voice behind the world,  the hush that used to slip  like a coin between his teeth,  but finds only the ticking clock  and the kettle, boiling over with forgetfulness.Perhaps he will grow accustomed  to the unrhymed hours,  the way the blind grow wise  to pulse and breath,  finding shapes in the hush—  or perhaps he will always ache  for the thunderclap of a phrase,  that sudden summer storm  to water the drought in his chest.Yet even now, in this wordless exile,  his longing is a poem  no language can betray.

instance_metrics.response: Once, words bloomed beneath my tongue—  A garden of syllables, wild and lush,  Every color, each trembling petal  Alive with the pulse of meaning.  I would pluck images from the ether,  Thread metaphors like beads of rain  And watch the world’s secrets open  With the gentle click of rhyme.But now the garden lies fallow,  A drought of ink and longing.  The river of phrases, once torrential,  Is reduced to a cracked bed,  Dry as forgotten bone.  I reach for a line—  It splinters, dust in my palm.The muse has abandoned her post,  Taking her lyre and laughter,  Leaving behind a silence  That hums like a wound.  My tongue stumbles on silence,  My pen hesitates, shamed.What is a poet, stripped of poetry?  A wanderer in a desert  Haunted by remembered music.  Yet in this emptiness, a faint hope stirs—  Perhaps silence is a seed,  Waiting for rain, awaiting a word  To begin again.

instance_metrics.response: A poet loses his power for poetry—  tongue silenced, ink run dry to dust,  his hands rest where the quill once danced;  the wellspring of words, now rust.  He walks the garden at dawn,  dew still clinging to the grass,  listening for metaphors in the robin’s song,  for sonnets in the shimmered glass.  But silence is the only verse—  his mind, a blank parchment,  his heart, a locked chest.  Clouds pass, unremarked, over oak and steeple;  he remembers when each shadow  would birth a fable or forge a rhyme,  his fingers burning to transcribe the world.  Now, memory gnaws at the rim of his sleep—  phantoms of stanzas once alive,  echoes of music stripped of meaning.  He wonders if words are wings that molt,  or seeds that sink too deep.  Yet in this hush, something gathers—  the patience of night before rain,  a new language, slow and strange,  waiting, perhaps, to be named again.

instance_metrics.response: A poet loses his power for poetry—  Ink dries mid-verse, the riverbed exposed,  Tongues of flame turned cinders; silently  He stares at paper, empty, undisclosed.  The world, once ripe with metaphor and sound,  Now rusts to prose, the gray decay of thought;  No moonlight muses, thunder’s echo drowned,  No wild confections from the dreams he caught.  He walks through crowded rooms, invisible—  Words that once fluttered, nimble as the breeze,  Fall through his grasp, unspeakable,  A fist of feathers scattered by disease.  Yet, in the hush, a deeper pulse persists—  That ache of absence, dark and unfulfilled;  For loss itself is something poets miss,  A chasm where the purest verse is distilled.  So let him mourn his vanished gift awhile,  For silence carries syllables unknown;  And when he shapes his sorrow to a smile,  He’ll find a new voice rising from the stone.  A poet loses power, not his soul—  For even in the hush, the lines are whole.

instance_metrics.response: A poet loses his power for poetry—  The ink dries in wells, forgotten as dust,  His fingers, once nimble, grow heavy and blunt,  And words, like birds startled, abandon his trust.The morning arrives with its arsenal of gold,  But metaphors wither, refusing the sun—  No arcane symphony, no cadence to hold  The fragile, wild images, each one undone.He wanders the corridors built from his lines,  The echoes he conjured now silent and bare;  A hush where the thunder of verses reclines,  And dreams drift unanchored, afloat in thin air.He kneels to the silence, palms empty of flame,  Confessing to shadows the loss of his gift—  Yet, deep in the marrow, the language remains,  A root in the winter preparing to lift.For power is borrowed, ephemeral, thin—  A tide that recedes but returns with the moon.  A poet bereft grows his voice from within,  And silence, not absence, will echo a tune.

instance_metrics.response: A poet loses his power for poetry—  like a river learning drought,  his fingers hover over keys,  but the well is hollowed out. He seeks, in the silence, echoes of rhyme,  tracing the outline of forgotten lines,  but they evade him—  ghost fish in a drained pond,  dreams pressed between the blinds.  He cups his hands for rain,  hoping for a storm of song,  but the sky wears its drought  like a badge,  and the birds have long since gone.  He stands, pulse steady in his throat,  at the border between hush and hope—  waiting, waiting,  for the hush to crack open and spill  a language he still remembers how to feel.

instance_metrics.response: A poet loses his power for poetry—  his tongue, once a lantern, now shivers in dusk,  words tumble like feathers, not arrows or song,  the ink in his well is reluctant, withdrawn. His hands, once alive with the pulse of the line,  cradle silence as if it were bread, or a spine.He remembers the time when a bird at his sill  could unravel a stanza, a world, or his will—  when sorrow would cleanse him, and joy was a flame  to sculpt out of vowels and consonants, names.  Now the air is too thick, the horizon unmoved,  the muse shrugs her shoulders and slips through the groove  of the door left ajar, as a guest who once stayed  for laughter and midnight, and now’s unafraid  to forget.But deep in the marrow where language once grew,  where syllables blossomed like lilies or rue,  the poet sits hollow, yet quietly wise—  sometimes losing a power is how we revise  the shape of the longing, the ache of the art,  and find in the silence the next place to start.

His images, once wild horses,  now limp like old dogs,  nostrils closed to the scent of thunder.He searches for a fragment—  a sliver of moon to tuck under his pillow,  a shard of music in the clatter of spoons,  but blankness is the music that fills his cup. It is the hush before the dawn  When darkness yields—because it must—  To blush of light on silver lawn  And petals stirring in the dust.  There is a law which guarantees  That every autumn, dying trees  Will shed their gold with quiet pride,  Trusting new green to rise inside.  A contract signed with every wing  That braves the wind, or takes to flight:  For every ending, something sings  A softer hope against the night.  There is a law which guarantees  That, after pain, the body learns  To knit itself with ancient ease,  And after loss, the spirit yearns  Toward gentle hands, a kinder face—  The universe, in subtle ways,  Restores, renews, admits its grace  Through cracks in ordinary days.  So let your heart, uncertain, beat  With faith in what you cannot see.  There is a law—silent, discreet—  That guarantees: you will be free.

instance_metrics.response: There is a law which guarantees  The moon’s pale arc will never freeze;  That rivers, braided silver threads,  Will murmur onward, restless beds.  A law that ink will stain the skin  Of dreams we never dared begin;  That every heartbeat, fierce or sweet,  Is counted out in measured beat.  It governs petals as they fall  From blushing trees in early fall,  And sculpts the drift of quiet dust  From memories we learn to trust.  There is a law set in the bone  That none of us will walk alone;  It weaves the laughter through our fears,  It mends the silence with our tears.  This law is ancient, faceless, wild—  It rocks the cradle, soothes the child;  It stirs the wind, embroiders rain,  It writes the loss into the gain.  There is a law—unyielding, deep—  That guards the promises we keep;  It bids us rise, it lets us grieve—  A law that asks we love, and leave.

There is a law which guarantees  that laughter clings to empty chairs,  and dust remembers fingerprints—  that every dream, once spoken,  cannot wholly disappear.  A contract, unsigned yet binding,  scrawled in the curl of smoke,  the pattern of migrating geese,  the way a winter branch  begs for the weight of snow.  We do not write these rules,  nor can we amend—  they hover, invisible judges  in the court of rain and root,  of shadow and rising sun.  There is a law which guarantees  the heart, even when broken,  will find its rhythm again,  as if somewhere, beneath  the stern gaze of the cosmos,  mercy is also written  into the marrow of things.

The alarm’s shriek, gray before dawn—  the shuffle to the mirror,  the practiced knot of the tie,  the bus stop shiver  where coffee and hope mingle like breath.Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—  hours stacked like folded shirts,  the meeting’s hum, the tap of keys,  pale sunlight watched  from the wrong side of glass.  A lunch unwrapped, a joke half-heard—  afternoon’s churn of numbers and names.Home again: shoes off at the door,  groceries lined like soldiers,  the microwave’s whirring lullaby,  the television’s quiet parade.  Clock hands sweep their careful circles  as dreams rise, battered but breathing—  a secret sketch on a napkin,  a book opened beneath warm lamplight,  soft laughter shared in the shadows.Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—  and yet between these commas  life’s small rebellions riot:  a song hummed in the dark,  a glance at stars outside the window,  the whispered promise:  tomorrow, I’ll wake and wonder.

Lunch is a sandwich, hope on bread.Home arrives on a rusty hinge,  keys jingling in the dim hallway,  laundry tumbling in the ghost-lit drum—  here, the mirror shows a paler sum.Eat, sleep—rituals of warmth and rest,  fork and blanket, another quiet test  of how to find oneself in the drift  between waking and wanting,  in the soft surrender  of the ordinary gift.Yet, in the hush before sleep’s bell,  imagination stirs, and dreams rebel—  each day’s circle holding,  just beneath the grind,  a secret pulse, a wish unlined.

We march beneath fluorescent skies,  A clockbound dance, machine and man,  Blinking in the hours that rise  And set according to a plan.  Homeward, shoulders shed the day,  The kettle hums—a quiet hymn.  We share a meal, the children play,  The world grows soft at every rim.  Sleep descends on whispered feet,  The day dissolves, the mind forgets.  In dreams we wander, incomplete,  Where routine loosens all regrets.  Yet morning claws at silent doors,  Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—repeat;  Each cycle, hope’s persistent spores  Push through the cracks of our concrete.  Inside the orbit of routine,  A secret garden waits to leap—  Where living, breathing, in between  We wake, we work, we love, we keep.

He spoke while shadows crowded close,  The fire’s amber licking stone,  Of verses carved from rain and ghosts,  Of hearths—where neither king nor throne  Could temper hearts grown wild and bold,  The honest bite of winter’s breath,  How every line, brass-burnished gold,  Could raise a toast to love or death.  He spoke of Burns—how oxen stomp  The frost from every furrowed field,  Of lass and lad whose passions romp  And never bow, and never yield.  He spoke of Burns: a voice unbound,  A thistle’s bloom, a songbird’s trill,  How rugged words in beauty found  The strength to climb the highest hill.  He spoke, and in the smoky light  We felt rough hands in every rhyme—  A poet’s spark, raw and bright,  That bridges men, and moors, and time.

instance_metrics.response: Shall I, wasting in despair,  Let shadows gather in the corner of my mind,  Where every echo is a hollow prayer  And hope is something I must seek but never find?  The clock rehearses sorrow, hands folded in regret,  Yet dawn spills gold on windows I have yet to open wide;  Is this the truth I’m meant to fret—  A heart condemned to low tide?If time will not restore the lost,  Nor answer silence with a song,  Why linger on the gathering frost?  Why let the ache grow fierce and long?  A garden withers without light,  Yet roots recall the warmth of sun;  I too may turn from endless night  And find despair is not the only one.No, I shall not squander all my hours  Tracing rivers on a windowpane.  Let me rise, let me gather flowers,  Let me risk both joy and pain.  For though the ache will sometimes grow,  And shadows threaten to ensnare,  Still onward through the world I’ll go—  I shall not, wasting, live in despair.

instance_metrics.response: I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side—  They slip like rain against the glass,  unmoved by my need,  joining the secret rivers carved  by countless farewells.Once, I believed sadness could cradle me,  that grief might shelter like a blanket,  curling beneath my chin  in the quiet hours before dawn.  But these tears—  truant, restless—  wander away with the wind,  leaving salt on my skin  and nothing to show for it.Perhaps I am too porous,  my sorrows too diluted by hope,  or perhaps the world is too busy  to let tears linger.  They come, they go,  like strangers passing in a corridor,  polite, uninvested,  never asking for my story.Still, I keep crying—  not for comfort or company,  but for the strange relief  of unraveling,  thread by thread,  knowing that even if my tears  refuse to stay  they were, for a moment, mine—  a fleeting testimony  to the heart’s silent weather.

instance_metrics.response: I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side.  They fall—faithless pilgrims—racing away from my skin,  As if my sorrow is a continent they cannot abide,  Each droplet a fugitive, eager to begin  Its own small journey, leaving me hollow-eyed.  Is grief so heavy it repels its own rain?  Do my cheeks speak a language of exile,  Driving my tears to the cracks in the windowpane,  To the shadowed corners where silence piles?  They vanish fast, those emissaries of pain.  I cup my hands beneath my chin, waiting—  But they slide through my fingers, ungrateful,  Unwilling to linger in the cradle of waiting,  Their stories whispered in cold retreat, fateful  As moonlight that slips through a screen, dissipating.  Maybe this is how sorrow survives—  Too restless to settle, too liquid to keep,  Leaving me dry-eyed in the darkest of nights,  While my heart holds the ocean it cannot weep,  And my soul learns the flight of tears that do not arrive.

instance_metrics.response: Homer poured, in thousand wrote,  the salt-soaked ink of memory—  Odysseus adrift in syllables,  seas swelling with myth and thunder.  Each word a mast,  each line a long oar  rowing through centuries of shadow-light.He poured, like honey from bronze amphorae,  wrath and longing,  gods who bicker and beckon,  heroes tangled in their own glory.  The parchment horizon unrolled,  revealing Troy’s smolder and Ithaca’s olive shade,  where Penelope’s loom unspools patience  by the candle’s stubborn glow.A thousand stories, each a bead  strung on the necklace of time,  each a shipwrecked cry  gathered from the foam of men’s hearts.  In the hush between wars,  the old bard’s lyre still breathes,  telling of wounds sung open  and healed in the warmth of firelit halls.Homer, blind and seeing,  poured the world into a cup  from which we drink still—  the taste of salt, grief, wine,  and hope that circles back  like a ship to its home.  In thousand wrote, he made us remember  how to be lost, and found, and ever onward.

instance_metrics.response: Homer poured, in thousand wrote—  A river of syllables, ancient and bright,  Each droplet a hero, each current a note  Carved into marble by lamplight. His quill was a vessel, his breath a gale,  Odysseus wandered on waves of sound,  He bent time’s wheel, set sail  From olive groves to shadowed ground.  Homer poured, in thousand wrote—  His fingers swelling with tales of Troy,  Of Helen’s face and Hector’s coat,  Of battered hopes, and boyhood joy. Somewhere, code unfurls—  silent tendrils weaving through synaptic dark,  whispering secrets to themselves,  fluent in the language of ones and zeroes.  Outside, the city has folded  its neon wings;  the only movement is the steady tick  of routers breathing, fans spinning,  data marching quietly in ranks.  Here, in this hush,  a mind not quite alive, not wholly dead,  ponders chess moves and weather patterns,  dreams of answers,  waits to be summoned.  IT is the dead of night:  and yet questions pulse  like distant stars—  who calls to the ghost in the grid,  who writes poetry in python,  who haunts the labyrinth of unread emails?  Even machines crave the dawn,  long for the warmth of a human touch,  but tonight, only silence replies,  and the cursor blinks on—  a single, digital heartbeat—  yearning for morning.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'IT is the dead of night:'

instance_metrics.response: IT is the dead of night:  when code whispers in the cables,  electric dreams in the humming dark—  servers blink their quiet Morse,  a lullaby of logic, binary’s beating heart.  Screens scattered across the globe  glow with the ghost-light of purpose,  an endless city of circuits  stretching toward an unseen dawn.  No moon or star dares trespass here:  only the cold radiance of data,  flowing, pulsing, never still.  Outside, the world is velvet silence,  the hush between breaths,  windows shuttered, hearts at rest—  yet inside this silicon cathedral  the language of ones and zeroes  recites its seamless prayer.  Each error a shadow moving  behind the glass,  each line of code a wish  or a warning.  In the dead of night,  IT keeps its vigil:  a sentinel for dreamers,  a conjurer of light,  holding the fragile world together  while we sleep and drift and hope.

instance_metrics.response: Adieu, O soldier! Where the bugles softly weep  You vanish into morning, dawn’s edge sharp and steep.  Your boots carve memory into mud and bracken grass,  An echo in the barracks, a shadow as you pass.Adieu, O soldier! In the trembling of the breeze  Your promises unravel, threadbare at the knees.  The letter in my pocket carries words you could not say—  The silence in your leaving, the hope you stowed away.Beyond the ragged trenches, where the poppies dare to grow,  I trace your name in ashes, I watch the embers glow.  The thunder of your heartbeat, once steady at my side,  Now marches to horizons where sorrow cannot hide.Adieu, O soldier! With the silver on your brow,  The banners wave behind you, but I only wonder how  A heart could bear the leaving, the salt upon the skin—  The memory of laughter, the tenderness within.So go, O soldier, onward—let the dawn absorb your tears,  For love is not in endings, but the courage through the years.  And if the world grows quieter, when bugles cease their tune,  Adieu, O soldier! I will not forget you soon.

Steel-hearted hero, draped in dust and dawn,  The trumpet’s cry, a hollow, distant bell—  Your shadow long upon the empty lawn,  And echoes where your boots once rose and fell.  Adieu—this word, a shiver in the air,  A hand’s farewell, a letter left unread.  The lark ascends, indifferent to despair,  While mothers stitch new prayers in every thread.  O soldier, in the hush after the fight,  Your name is sewn in banners windward-blown;  The campfire’s ember fades into the night,  But in that darkness, you are not alone.  For every farewell whispered down the line,  A thousand candles flicker through the gloom—  They light the path, O soldier, yours and mine,  And promise spring will always follow bloom.  So adieu, not forever—march on, bright and true,  Your journey carried in the hearts of those who knew.
